Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Story: I woke up early, the scent of incense already drifting through the house. Today was the day of our family’s annual ceremony, and my mother’s voice echoed in my mind: “You must lead this year, it’s your turn to honor our ancestors.” I felt the weight of her expectation, the pride in her eyes, and the importance of not letting my family down. But as I glanced at my phone, a message from my supervisor blinked on the screen: “Full house deep clean today. Every room spotless. No exceptions.” My job as a housekeeping cleaner paid our bills, and I knew how much my boss relied on me to keep the standards high. I could picture the dust in the corners, the streaks on the windows, the checklist waiting for my signature. My heart pounded as I stood between the altar and the mop, torn by the pull of tradition and the demands of work. Both roles needed me, both expected my best, and I could feel the pressure building, unsure which path to take.
